pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [12b8f4db8d](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20324/commits/12b8f4db8da4f1881f83676e2a9d5a93ad03dc87)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.RingTheory.Etale.Field | 1901 | 1905 | +4 (+0.21%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.Etale.Field`|4|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.Etale.Pi` (new file)|1455|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Algebra.Etale.iff_exists_algEquiv_prod`
`+ iff_exists_algEquiv_prod`
`+ pi_iff`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
The imports of `MaximalSpectrum` should be pretty light now, and you can feel free to import it. I need to change the file Artinian to use it though ...
I take it back; it's still heavy enough that you can't import it freely without acquiring the large-import label ...
I think in the text we should include the accent and write "étale", as is the case with people's names etc.
I think we do anglicize people's name in docstrings e.g. `Kaehler` instead of `Kähler` or `Nakayama` instead of `中山`

"étale" is [pretty common](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Aleanprover-community%2Fmathlib4+%C3%A9tale&type=code) in mathlib, and I think usages of "Kaehler" should be corrected. Mathlib uses Unicode freely (declaration names being the only exception), and I don't see why this doesn't apply to people's names in docstrings. I think the purpose of using Unicode is to make things look like they appear in mainstream mathematical texts. You will find "étale" in every book, Wikipedia, and Stacks Project, but it's not common to find "中山" in English text. This should be the general criterion to determine what spelling we use in mathlib.
My reference (Iversen) uses `etale` instead of `étale` but either way is fine for me. Changed.

For this type of theorems, I think it might be better to separate the forward and backward directions. For the forward direction you can use `Fin n` instead of an arbitrary indexing type. For the backward direction you can take `I` and `Ai` in any universe, and the conclusion could simply say `FormallyEtale K (Π i, Ai i)` (this could be an instance, but a more generaly instance would assume each `Ai i` is formally etale); you can add a separate lemma saying that `FormallyEtale K` is invariant under `K`-AlgHoms. This would ensure both directions are maximally general, but I understand it may need additional infrastructure, like `congrLeft` constructions (on the indexing type) for various kinds of algebraic isomorphisms (AlgHom here).

I think we won't be using the backwards direction of this lemma much as there is already `Algebra.FormallyEtale.pi_iff`. As for the forward direction, I'm not sure I see the point of indexing with `Fin n` instead of an arbitrary finite type.
Okay, I won't insist that you change this.

pullRequest.title: feat(RingTheory): classification of etale algebras over fields
